headline: Former Man United midfielder Paul Pogba receives 'boost' ahead of doping ban hearing
body: Former Manchester United midfielder Paul Pogba is reportedly set to begin his battle to overturn a four-year doping ban at the Court of Arbitration for Sport next week.
The 31-year-old, who cost United a world-record £89m in 2016, was slapped with a four-year ban earlier this year after failing a drugs test following Juventus' 3-0 win against Udinese last August.

Pogba's suspension came after Italy's anti-doping tribunal, NADO, found elevated levels of testosterone in his system. The positive test was later confirmed after a second sample was tested in October and resulted in Pogba being slapped with a four-year suspension from the game.
According to the Daily Mail, Pogba's appeal is set to be heard by CAS next week just days after the midfielder was provided with fresh hope that he could reverse his career-ending ban.

That's after world No.1 tennis player Jannik Sinner escaped a ban despite failing two anti-doping tests back in March. The Italian was initially slapped with a suspension but later saw it overturned after he claimed that his positive test for the banned anabolic steroid clostebol was a result of contamination through his physiotherapist.
The Mail adds that the ruling surrounding Sinner has been "acknowledged" by the Pogba camp and will be a "key development" as the 2018 World Cup winner looks to fight his suspension.
After being hit with the suspension back in February, Pogba vehemently denied the claims and insisted he was "sad, shocked and heartbroken" by the verdict.

"I have today been informed of the Tribunale Nazionale Antidoping’s decision and believe that the verdict is incorrect," said the midfielder on Instagram. "I am sad, shocked and heartbroken that everything I have built in my professional playing career has been taken away from me."When I am free of legal restrictions the full story will become clear, but I have never knowingly or deliberately taken any supplements that violate anti-doping regulations."As a professional athlete I would never do anything to enhance my performance by using banned substances and have never disrespected or cheated fellow athletes and supporters of any of the teams I have played for, or against."As a consequence of the decision announced today I will appeal this before the Court of Arbitration for Sport."

headline: Man United wait on Premier League rival for transfer move as 'astronomical' bid ready
body: Manchester United are reportedly waiting on Fulham before deciding whether to bid for their left-back Antonee Robinson this summer.

United's left-back position is a source of concern for Erik ten Hag this summer with both Luke Shaw and Tyrell Malacia suffering with injury issues these past two seasons. Noussair Mazraoui is able to cover on the left flank but there is some speculation that United may want a player who is recognised in that position.

According to GiveMeSport, the Reds are monitoring Robinson as the player to provide cover at left-back. However, they are waiting to see if the London club move for Fenerbahce's Ferdi Kadioglu before making an approach for the American.

The thought process is believed to be that should Kadioglu sign for Fulham, then Robinson's game time will be hampered and thus the Reds would have a better chance of bringing him to Old Trafford for a lower price. Elsewhere, Inter are reportedly set to blow United out of the water for Juventus winger Federico Chiesa.

According to Sport, United are one of five teams believed to have shown an interest in the Italian winger. It is understood Chiesa would be allowed to leave Juventus should a reasonable bid be submitted.

However, the Reds are unlikely to sign the 26-year-old now with Inter preparing an 'astronomical' wage offer for the forward. There is thought to be some hope for United if they find the money for a new winger as Juve would prefer to sell him to a club abroad rather than enhance a direct rival.
United though would need to make a sale in the final third of the pitch before signing any more attacking players.

headline: Manchester United edging closer to Manuel Ugarte signing after Paris St-Germain talks
body: Manchester United are close to agreeing a deal to sign Manuel Ugarte from Paris St-Germain after productive talks with the French giants.

Ugarte has been United's top midfield target throughout the summer and the 23-year-old has been desperate to make the move to Old Trafford, but the two clubs were some way apart in their valuation during talks earlier in the window.

But Ugarte was left out of the PSG squad for their opening fixture of the Ligue 1 campaign last weekend and further talks have been held between the two clubs this week, with a deal now thought to be imminent. That is likely to be a season-long loan move with an obligation to buy.

United have held firm on their valuation of the Uruguayan international and there was an expectation PSG would be willing negotiators. They need to sell players after another summer of heavy spending, including signing 19-year-old midfielder Joao Neves from Benfica for €60m.

United were confident of landing Ugarte a week ago and during talks for other midfielders expressed confidence that they would get a deal done. A loan move wouldn't necessitate the sale of Scott McTominay, but the club remain open to offers for Casemiro and Christian Eriksen.

Ugarte would be the fifth signing of the summer after Leny Yoro, Joshua Zirkzee, Matthijs de Ligt and Noussair Mazraoui. United have spent £156m on players so far during the window with a net spend in excess of £80m.

headline: Manchester United are copying Man City transfer trick to beat FFP concerns
body: Facundo Pellistri might no longer be a Manchester United player, but club officials will hope the winger continues to shine as he begins his career away from Old Trafford.

The Uruguayn's permanent exit was confirmed with a £5.1m move to Panathinaikos on Wednesday, with a further £1.7m due in add-ons, but the most eye-catching part of the deal was the size of the sell-on United had negotiated with the Greek outfit.

Whether Pellistri shines or not in Greece, United will pocket 45% of his next fee. If the 21-year-old is sold at a loss that won't amount to much, but if he thrives for regular game time and lands a bigger move, then a substantial sum could be heading back to fill the coffers at Old Trafford. Pellistri will hope to find his way back to a big five European league and United will hope he can achieve that as well.

Sell-on clauses have gradually become more common in the game and United are starting to latch on. Almost all of the deals they have done for the sale of academy players this summer have included sizeable clauses and one will be included when Maxi Oyedele finalises his move to Legia Warsaw.

There was what was described as a 'sizeable' sell-on clause included when Willy Kambwala left to join Villarreal and around a 50% clause included in the deal that took Mason Greenwood to Marseille. United also included a sell-on when Alvaro Fernandez joined Benfica while most agreements also include buy-back clauses.

This is now the common structure when academy graduates are sold and United have made up ground in this department. They have certainly been more proactive around selling young players since Erik ten Hag arrived at the club, with Anthony Elanga, Zidane Iqbal, Matej Kovar, Teden Mengi, Axel Tuanzebe, Ethan Laird, Charlie Savage, Noam Emeran, and Marc Jurado all leaving last summer.

In Ten Hag's first summer in charge James Garner was the headline academy departure, moving to Everton when a 15% sell-on clause was included. United are tending to get higher percentages now and it is sometimes worth accepting a smaller fee to land the higher clause, protecting the club if the player suddenly thrives with exposure to regular football.

United are yet to see a major benefit to these deals, but it's no surprise they are getting higher clauses in deals when two former Manchester City powerbrokers now work for the club, in chief executive Omar Berrada and technical director Jason Wilcox. City lead the way when it comes to profiting from academy sales and often doing so twice.

This summer they banked around £10m from the deals that took Aro Muric from Burnley to Ipswich and Douglas Luiz from Aston Villa to Juventus. They could cash-in again if James Trafford is sold by Burnley and collected twice in quick succession last year when Romeo Lavia left Southampton to sign for Chelsea.

In an era defined by stricter spending controls, buy-back clauses are becoming a key weapon for big clubs. United have had to sell to buy this summer and could yet be forced to sell Scott McTominay to raise the funds to sign Manuel Ugarte.
The £40m or so they have raised from selling Greenwood, Kambwala, Pellistri and Fernandez has been helpful, but the fees heading to United for that quartet won't end there.

headline: Who is Sekou Kone? Meet Man United new wonderkid signing who has secret Tottenham link

headline: Anthony Elanga sparks Man United backlash with social media post about star’s transfer away
body: Anthony Elanga's cryptic response to Maxi Oyedele's departure from Manchester United has angered supporters of the club.

The Swedish forward ended his seven-year stay at Old Trafford last summer, completing a £15million switch to Nottingham Forest. He went on to play a key role in their 2023/24 season success, helping them stay up in the Premier League.

Remaining close with many at Manchester United, the 22-year-old took to Instagram with a cryptic message following Oyedele's revelation that he's departing the Premier League giants after a 12-year spell, signing with Poland's Legia Warsaw, reports the Mirror.

Although Oyedele, 19, failed to make an appearance in United's first team, he expressed deep sentiments about the club, saying it will "always be my home" while announcing his exit on the social media platform.

"My time at Manchester United has finally come to an end. I want to say thank you to the only club I've ever known," the midfielder wrote. "Honoured to say I've been at the club for 12 years and had some unbelievable experiences with some amazing teammates.

"Thank you to all the coaches, staff and the fans, I will never forget the memories I have made at this club. I wish everyone at Manchester United all the best as I leave ready to start the next chapter of my career. This club will always be my home and once again thank you. Once a red, always a red."

Various United talents expressed their good wishes in the comments as Oyedele announced his move to a new club, with Kobbie Mainoo writing: "My brother, all the best" and recent acquisition Leny Yoro adding: "All the best bro".

Instead of leaving a message, Elanga responded to Oyedele's post with a gif displaying a character from 'The Matrix' evading bullets, which has somewhat irked fans who interpreted it as the youngster 'dodging a bullet' by leaving.

Some Instagram users suggested humour was at play, with one remarking: "probs an inside joke to them" while another fan didn't shirk from directly addressing Elanga, implying he wasn't stellar during his tenure in Manchester, commenting: "Let's be perfectly honest, the best thing about Elanga was his song".

One observer bluntly wrote: "Elanga was given a chance in the United first team and couldn't hold down a spot. He simply wasn't good enough," and another added: "Elanga is a hater. The path to the 1st team is as clear as daylight and Garnacho and Mainoo have shown that, so will Collyer and Amass. Not everyone can make it."

Furthermore, several supporters pinned 'salty' and 'bitter' tags on him due to what they see as an indirect swipe at the club. Last year, after Elanga's remarks describing Nottingham Forest's 2-1 triumph over United as "personal" following a challenging spell at his former squad, there were rumours about a potential rift with manager Erik ten Hag.

Elanga, however, quashed speculation that the Dutchman's influence led to his Old Trafford exit in a chat with SoccerNews. nl, insisting: "Was Ten Hag the reason I left United? No, I wouldn't say that," adding: "I just wanted to play, that was especially important to me. I'm young and I don't want to sit on the bench all season, you know?

headline: Manchester United pay the price for not addressing priority position in Brighton defeat
body: Manchester United must have hoped this season had closed the book on last season. Already it feels like an extension of the same chapter with another defeat in added time.

After Arsenal, Fulham and Chelsea gave United a dosage of their own Fergie Time medicine, Brighton are the latest. This was reminiscent of the chaos that engulfed United in Erik ten Hag's second campaign when they shipped 20 goals in the 80th minute and beyond. Brighton inflicted an added-time loss on United two seasons ago, too.

United's performance peaked in the first half. They ended that behind and when they did equalise on the hour it was against the run of play. If the victory over Fulham was a performance to build on, United have already crumbled.

Ten Hag's in-game management will be scrutinised again. Their midfield left their back four exposed too often again. Kobbie Mainoo appears overburdened after a taxing nine months and the cumbersome Casemiro continues to start by default. Both somehow played out the full duration.
That is on United's hierarchy as much as Ten Hag, for they have still not reinforced the central midfield, which had to be prioritised. The need for Manuel Ugarte is more urgent now.

Beyond Mainoo, that department is shambolic. Ten Hag instead turned to Scott McTominay on possibly his farewell appearance. Antony arrived even later and his only impact was to concede a free-kick. Christian Eriksen has as much matchday involvement as a mascot.
There is possibly another injury for United to contend with, too. Mason Mount made way at the interval and his replacement, Joshua Zirkzee, was a goal-stopper rather than goalscorer.

Ten Hag will dwell on Amad's chance at 0-0 and Zirkzee's fateful intervention at 1-1. For the second successive week, substitutes Zirkzee and Alejandro Garnacho combined, only this time the offside Zirkzee was on the line to lucklessly divert Garnacho's goalbound tap-in over the line.

Garnacho had just got back to the dugout from a thorough warm up when Amad received the ball. It was soon bouncing around the Brighton net. Amad was mourning the death of his step-mother on Friday but requested to play. On this, his fifth successive Premier League start, he lashed in his fourth United goal.

There are particular prerequisites for a proper United winger and Amad undeniably possesses the resilience the club's greats had. He fluffed two goalscoring opportunities in a blunt first half but was sharp with his equaliser in the second.
He will rue his miscued volley in the first half. That would have made it 1-0, rather than 1-1. United's wastefulness in front of goal has cost them two effective defeats before the end of August.

There was a pat on the head from Amad when he earned a breather in the 90th minute. Ruud van Nistelrooy embraced him and there was more back-slapping from teammates before their heads dropped five minutes later.

Across their three fixtures this month, Amad, Marcus Rashford and Bruno Fernandes have each squandered at least two auspicious opportunities. Garnacho and Mount were impotent against Fulham, too, and the Zirkzee bounce denied them a 2-1 advantage at Brighton.
That is at least nine good or great goalscoring openings. United have scored three times. Two of the three goals they have sieved have been in the 89th and 95th minute.

Wing play influenced the scoreline. Kaoru Mitoma, sorely missed by Brighton last term, capitalised on Harry Maguire's uncertainty from Joao Pedro's centre and Welbeck crowned the tenth anniversary of his departure from his boyhood club with a sixth goal against United and the 100th of his impressive career.
Welbeck, hugged by Van Nistelrooy during a stoppage, was applauded by the grateful United supporters when he was withdrawn. The nippy Simon Adingra crossed for the unmarked Pedro in the 95th minute.

Zirkzee was one of four substitutes to warm up at the pause and his was the most rigorous as he was put through his paces by the United fitness coach Charlie Owen. Zirkzee replaced Mount, United's standout player of the half.

The second half had barely got underway and Ten Hag instructed Garnacho to prepare for his introduction. After Rashford was flagged offside again in the 56th minute, United supporters broke into a rendition of "Viva Garnacho", imploring Ten Hag to send on their game-changer.
Garnacho soon crossed the white line for Rashford. Goalless after three games this term and his performance level has gradually waned in these opening weeks.

Early on, Ten Hag recommended Rashford reposition himself elsewhere. Rashford soon switched to the other flank, out of earshot, and was trapped offside from Andre Onana's clipped pass. Rashford vented, seemingly at Onana. Back on the left, he was much more histrionic at the defensive distribution.

United resolved to spring Rashford through, only he was often offside. Even in the first phase prior to his disallowed goal, Rashford strayed ahead of the final man. Van Nistelrooy, a master of manipulating the offside rule years before the inception of the Video Assistant Referee, wagged his finger.

Rashford's body language and impatience bear the hallmarks of a goalscorer struggling to score goals. The first half drew to a close with Rashford attempting a crossfield punt that was blocked. He glanced at the heavens. The rainfall got heavier. Rashford was still warmly applauded by the United followers he walked past when his number flashed up.

Mount set out his stall with more harrying, beckoning his teammates into the final third after cornering Jan Paul van Hecke. Mount's switch of play to accelerate an attack drew applause from the optimistic United fans.
It was the best and most influential 45 minutes from Mount in a United shirt. Gallingly for him, he was removed at the interval, a change likely enforced by injury.

Ten Hag was piqued by Lisandro Martinez and Diogo Dalot's positioning for their collaborations. Seconds later, Dalot dexterously created a glaring opening for Amad entirely of his own making. A goal continued to elude United's starting forwards until Amad regained the ball.
If only for United he put it in at 0-0.

headline: Why Alejandro Garnacho's Manchester United strike was ruled out by VAR vs Brighton
body: Manchester United will leave the Amex Stadium this afternoon wondering what might of been had VAR not chalked off Alexandro Garnacho's strike in the 70th minute.. The Red Devils were beaten 2-1 by Fabian Hurzeler's Brighton side with Joao Pedro scoring at the death to maintain their impressive start to the campaign.

The Red Devils thought they'd grabbed an important goal with just 20 minutes of the game remaining after a brilliant counter-attack, working the ball out to Bruno Fernandes in space on the right-hand side of the pitch, before combining well with Amad Diallo. The Portuguese playmaker fizzed a ball into the box with Joshua Zirkzee sliding in to try and get on the end of it, but missed the ball.

Garnacho was lurking at the far post and managed to get on the end of the cross and send the ball goal-bound. Unfortunately for United, the ball deflected off the Dutch striker on its way into the net, just inches away from the line.

The goal was given by the on-field officials, but VAR checked for a potential offside against Zirkzee and it was ruled out despite the strike being a certain goal regardless of the small touch. Play restarted with a Brighton free-kick with the scores still level after a Danny Welbeck opener and Amad Diallo equaliser.

Both teams were pushing for a late winner but it was the hosts who snatched all three points. Simon Adingra was slipped into the box down the left, picking out Pedro at the far post to break the deadlock in the 95th minute to break United hearts.

Premier League Match Centre, the operational hub for all Premier League games confirmed the reason. They tweeted: "Zirkzee’s goal was awarded on-field. The VAR checked for a potential offside against Zirkzee and recommended that the goal was disallowed. Play restarted with a Brighton free-kick."

headline: Erik ten Hag has invented new Manchester United role after Joshua Zirkzee impact
body: Erik ten Hag has told his Manchester United substitutes to think of themselves as "finishers" after seeing two of them win the game on the opening weekend of the season.

United's bench has had a productive start to the season, with Alejandro Garnacho scoring as a sub in the Community Shield, before the winger came on against Fulham to set up Joshua Zirkzee's debut goal.

Garnacho and Zirkzee will hope that impact will get them into the team for Saturday's Premier League fixture with Brighton but Ten Hag has designs on a deep squad this season and admits some players will have to accept not being in the matchday 20 at times.
For those who do make the squad but find themselves on the bench, Ten Hag has called on them to be ready to go and win a game, just as Garnacho and Zirkzee did last week.

Rebranding replacements as 'finishers' was something the coach of England's Rugby Union team Eddie Jones did, with that trick copied by Gareth Southgate during this summer's European Championship. Ten Hag now wants a similar approach from his squad, having told players they must accept they won't play every game.
"You have to accept it, make sure you are in the first XI, make sure you are in the first 20," he said. "You have to prove it, show it every day on the training pitch and in every minute you can get.

"It is not only about the starters it is also about the finishers. I was very pleased last week that Zirkzee and Garnacho made the difference, one gave the assist and the other made the goal, that is what we need across the whole season. You don’t win with 11 players, in games but also between games, you need more than 11 players to win the football games."

Ten Hag has been keen to get the message across early in the season that players will have to accept missing out at times this season, citing Jadon Sancho's reaction to not being selected against Arsenal last September as something not to be repeated.

The Dutchman wants a positive reaction from his squad whatever a player's status and said the group must reflect on what happened with Sancho and take lessons from it, while explaining his stance on discussing a decision with an individual..

"I think as a squad we have to reflect on that situation, there are things that are going to happen this season and we have to deal with it because that player can make the difference in the next game, next five games, because we have players in the squad who are all capable of playing in the first 11, or at least the first 15," he said.

"Each case is different. You can't explain for every game, but of course when the player has questions, when he doesn't understand I am always open to a conversation. Sometimes I will take the initiative but you can't explain for every game why you make so many decisions, you can’t explain them all."

headline: Manchester United winger Amad shows true colours vs Brighton after tragic announcement
body: Amad was included in Manchester United's matchday squad for the trip to Brighton just hours after he shared some tragic personal news.

United face the Seagulls at the Amex Stadium in their first away clash of the Premier League season. Erik ten Hag's side go into the fixture on the back of a 1-0 win over Fulham last weekend and will be looking for another three points this time around.

Amad was named in the starting line-up for the victory over Fulham last week. And the 22-year-old was once again included in the starting line-up for the Saturday lunchtime kick-off on the south coast

The decision by Ten Hag to start Amad comes after the United forward announced the tragic news of his brother's mum's passing. Amad clarified the news on social media on Friday night, after there was confusion that his biological mother had passed away.
"Rest in peace Mum, may Allah forgive you," Amad initially wrote on Snapchat.
Clarifying his announcement, the United forward later wrote on X: "Guys I wanted to clarify. She is not my biological mother, she is my brother's mother and my sister. May she rest in peace."

Amad was selected to start on the right wing by Ten Hag, putting the tragic news behind him to turn in a solid performance for his team. headline: Vincent Kompany responds to 'stupid' Matthijs de Ligt theory after Manchester United transfer
body: Vincent Kompany reportedly did not want to sell Matthijs de Ligt amid claims he told the player he was his number one defender heading into the new season.

De Ligt was one of four major signings for Manchester United this summer, alongside Joshua Zirkzee, Leny Yoro and Noussair Mazraoui. According to a report from the Athletic, the player was told by Kompany that he was not responsible for his sale and that he was his number one centre-back.
It's said that De Ligt's camp felt that a choice had been made at board level. However, a spokesperson for Bayern has denied that Kompany ever said 'words to that effect.'

The report also claims that De Ligt's camp felt Bayern were 'playing a game' during talks over his future. When asked about those claims, Kompany said: "It would've been so stupid of me to say something like that. It wouldn't fit with what we've planned for the entire squad. It makes no sense."

Meanwhile, Bayern director of sport Max Eberl added: "We don't make decisions based on fan favourites; we have to decide where we feel we have the best chance of success. We are the last ones who want to talk bad about Matthijs.
"He played very solidly. But we made a different decision at centre-back, and we wanted to have a left-footed player, which is why we went with Hiroki [Ito]."

De Ligt, meanwhile, was determined to reunite with his former boss Erik ten Hag after their days at Ajax. "Erik ten Hag shaped the early stages of my career, so he knows how to get the best out of me and I cannot wait to work with him again," he told United club media. He should start down the middle and Fernandes should be relocated to his natural position in attacking midfield, which would see Mason Mount axed from the starting side.
Garnacho or Amad?
After a superb pre-season, Amad started on the opening day against Fulham and whether he did enough in that game to retain his role against Brighton is questionable.
Although Amad looked bright when on the ball, he wasn't in the game enough and Alejandro Garnacho provided the assist for Zirkzee's goal after replacing him on the hour mark.

Garnacho also scored in the Community Shield - he took that goal brilliantly - and it feels inevitable he'll return to the starting team. The youngster has the ability to take his game to another level this term and he must eventually provide more goals and assists at crucial moments.
United used Garnacho's pace to play over Brighton's highline in May and it wouldn't be a surprise to see him play another key role in the tactical plan to exploit the opposition.
Brighton's new manager

Brighton are one of the best-run football clubs in the world. Their data-led recruitment allows them to sign quality players for minimal fees and flip them in multi-million transfers just a few years later and that recipe for success saw them embark into European competition last term.
Roberto de Zerbi led Brighton into the Europa League, but he departed at the end of last season to join Marseille and he's been replaced by Fabian Hurzeler, who is just 31 years old.

Hurzeler was aged six when United won the treble in 1999 and Casemiro, Christian Eriksen and Tom Heaton are older than him. The German is a rising star in the coaching sphere and he warned Brighton would have to 'suffer' at times against United on Saturday afternoon.
"I games like Manchester United there will be moments where we have to suffer together," he said in his press conference. "There will be moments where maybe United control the game.

"And then you have to stand together, then you have to suffer together. I would love if the fans are still behind us and supporting us. That’s our job, to build this connection with the fans, and it only works if we give a lot of input and a lot of energy on the pitch, and a lot of intensity.”
You'll not be alone in watching Saturday's game and feeling old watching Hurzeler on the sideline.
De Ligt or Maguire?
Matthijs De Ligt has been signed to start and the expectation is he will partner Lisandro Martinez, but Harry Maguire started on the opening day and won't give up his place without a fight.
Maguire enjoyed a renaissance last term and clawed his way back into the starting side, despite losing the captaincy, and will make more starts in 2024/25 than most expect him to.
The former club captain performed well against Fulham and deserves to retain his starting place this weekend, which means the wait for De Ligt's full deal should continue.
Removing Maguire from the team on the back of a faultless performance would send the wrong message in the dressing room and De Ligt can contribute off the bench again.
Has anyone seen Sancho?
Jadon Sancho was a notable absentee when United faced Fulham and Ten Hag, speaking to journalists after the win, confirmed that was partly due to an ear infection and partly tactical.
Ten Hag clarified that Sancho was fit enough to be included in the 20-man quad but he opted to name Garnacho, Zirkzee and Antony as the attacking substitutes instead.
The 24-year-old has been pictured in training ahead of the Brighton game but he could be left out again, which shouldn't be a surprise given his situation with the United boss last season.
Ideally, Sancho would be sold in this summer transfer window, however, there are six days remaining for business and there doesn't seem to be a market for him.

headline: Manuel Ugarte terms agreed, Ivan Toney signs - Man United dream end to transfer window
body: Manchester United have done the heavy lifting when it comes to their recruitment drive this summer.

However, with nine days remaining for Premier League clubs to strike up further business, there might yet be more to come from Ineos and key figures behind the scenes. United are still in the market for another midfielder and their prime candidate - as it has been for several weeks - is Manuel Ugarte from PSG.

It was thought that the proposed deal was dependent on outgoings - which are still being considered - but United are 'open' to a late change in approach for the Uruguay regular. The Manchester Evening News understands a loan with the option to buy could be priced-up to help them get Ugarte over the line before August 30.

United are, meanwhile, prepared to sell five more players including Jadon Sancho this summer. Here, our dedicated reporters take a look at what could happen around Old Trafford between now and next Friday night's deadline, and offer up their dream scenarios for the closing days;

Manuel Ugarte is a deal which needs to happen for United to call this transfer window a success. The midfielder could be United's most important signing of the summer and the difference between them finishing in the top four or not.

Whilst Casemiro has looked better in the early stages of 2024/25, the 32-year-old cannot be relied upon for another season. After signing Ugarte, United's next priority should be selling several players who don't have a long-term future at Old Trafford, starting with Jadon Sancho.

Victor Lindelof is another player who should go, although with his current injury that seems unlikely, whilst Christian Eriksen won't be much use this season. Scott McTominay may be worth keeping though, providing it doesn't impact a deal for Ugarte.

The Scotland international proved his worth for Ten Hag's team last season and still remains a useful squad player. What United don't want though is keeping someone who doesn't want to be there which may necessitate a sale, regardless of how much he still offers.

Heading into these final stages of the summer transfer window, United should have a clear goal in mind - signing a midfielder. To finance this, the Reds will more than likely need to sell McTominay which, for the right price, would be good business.

If United can receive their valuation of £40m they will be laughing at that and considering the panic in the Napoli camp at present, this could well be doable too. After bringing in the money for the Scottish central player it is more than likely that Ugarte will be added to the team.

The jury is out on the Uruguayan at present but there is still plenty of time for him to reach the heights needed to be a starter for United. Once again, the big issue here will be regarding his price tag with a loan move perhaps the wisest decision for now.

After that, I am not sure that United would need to do any more business or be in a position to do any more for that matter. Sancho's sale is not necessarily the priority it once was and if the hatchet has well and truly been buried, there is no reason why he could not be a force this season.
A loan deal for Manuel Ugarte looks to be on the cards for United in between now and the end of the transfer window. That signing would fill the position where the United squad are most in need.

Getting the deal done on an initial loan does mean that funds raised through sales for the move won’t be so important between now and the end of the window. Therefore if no team reaches the £40 million asking price for Scott McTominay, then he will stay at Old Trafford for at least another six months before the situation is looked at again in January.

Another source of income from player sales is Jadon Sancho. While the situation surrounding the public fall-out between him and Ten Hag now looks to have been resolved, it still feels that the player’s future lies away from Old Trafford. United have reportedly set an asking price of around £40 million, if they can get that, it would serve as a boost ahead of the January window.

There’s no real other areas of the squad that obviously need strengthening for the remainder of the season. If the Ugarte signing gets over the line then the concentration should therefore be on outgoings.

On paper, the dream scenario for United between now and 11pm on August 30 is rather simple. However, due to complex deals taking shape and one or two players facing uncertain futures at the club, the business that should map out - both in and out of Old Trafford - is anything but straightforward.
A permanent sale for Scott McTominay would enable United to press ahead with Manuel Ugarte.

Amid one or two question marks over his transfer fee, though, Ineos might be better-served following their 'new' plan and signing the Uruguay international on loan instead. That would allow them to keep McTominay around for one final year as his goals would be an additional bonus in a reduced, bit-part role.

Cashing in on Jadon Sancho would be ideal, too, to perhaps allow United to bring in another striker. Ivan Toney is not exactly an essential recruit, but he could be a useful addition to injured Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee up top if United feel the need to spend whatever money they get from Sancho on an alternative profile.

United's dream end to the transfer window would start with cashing in on Jadon Sancho and Scott McTominay before reinvesting that income into their defence and midfield. Victor Lindelof should also be off, freeing up his wages more than necessarily a transfer fee.

Manuel Ugarte seems to be who they want, so agreeing to a loan deal with Paris Saint-Germain would be ideal, with an option rather than an obligation to buy the Uruguay international. Then, the dream scenario would be returning for Jarrad Branthwaite and signing the third central defender that the club have been open to signing this summer.

That would represent a complete overhaul of the position and be necessary after offloading Lindelof. Branthwaite, Matthijs de Ligt and Leny Yoro would finally adequately address that problem position in the squad, allowing the new hierarchy to address other areas over the coming windows.

headline: Who is Jim Thwaites? The 16-year-old training with Manchester United first team ahead of Brighton
body: Manchester United are stepping up their preparations for the first away game of the 2024/15 Premier League season.

Erik ten Hag’s side started the campaign on a positive note with new signing Joshua Zirkzee getting the only goal of the game in last Friday’s 1-0 Premier League win over Fulham as the team kicked off the new campaign. Concentration now turns to the trip to Brighton.
United take on the Seagulls at the AMEX Stadium on Saturday (12.30pm kick-off). Fabian Hurzeler’s side started with a 3-0 win over Everton last weekend, leaving them at the top of the early table.

Ahead of the game, Ten Hag has been putting his first-team squad through their paces. Included in the group was teenager Jim Thwaites, who at just 16 is considered as one of the club’s leading prospects.
So who is Thwaites? MEN Sport has taken a closer look at the youngster.

Thwaites is a 16-year-old central midfielder who has come up through the youth teams at Old Trafford. He was one of 10 players to sign a first-year scholarship deal earlier this summer, with young players not able to sign professional deals until they are 17 years old.

He featured for the club’s U16, U18, and U21 sides last season, winning the Goal of the Season award at both U16 and U18 levels. He made nine appearances for the U18s, his goal being a crucial equaliser in the 2-2 draw with Derby County.

His two appearances for the development squad came as a second-half substitute in the Premier League 2 clashes against Derby and Middlesbrough. This year he is expected to be given a prominent role in the U18s side and awarded with the experience of joining in with first-team training.

Taking to Instagram after his Goal of the Season awards, the teenager promised there was ‘more to come’ in the upcoming campaign. Sharing a clip of both of the goals on his Instagram, he wrote: “Delighted to get both U16 and U18 goal of the season. More to come next season…”

He has also given his response to training with the United first team for the first time. On Wednesday night he posted a picture of his boots on his Instagram story with a caption reading: “Good first session with the first team.”

headline: New role, dream partnership - How Manuel Ugarte transfer can unlock three Man United stars
body: Manchester United are looking to bring defensive midfielder Manuel Ugarte into their team before the end of the summer transfer window next week.

The Uruguayan midfielder comes with big expectations to meet in the centre, particularly after last season's woes in the middle of the park. Too often United found themselves cut open with the mix-and-match central defenders left unprotected from the attacking hordes.

Casemiro was often blamed as being off the pace in the midfield which forced United to lack a defensively minded player in the centre. Upon his arrival at Old Trafford, you would expect Ugarte to form a partnership with Kobbie Mainoo.

During the summer, we saw how Mainoo blossomed alongside Declan Rice for England at the European Championships and having a player who can effectively mop up in front of the back line should allow Mainoo to roam forward and show off his attacking capabilities. One person who is confident Ugarte can produce this role is former United striker Diego Forlan.

He told ESPN Uruguay last year that he had spotted the midfielder's potential early and expressed: "He is very important in the middle to free Valverde and Bentancur. Defensively he adds a lot. If I were a coach, I would love to put Ugarte in the middle."
Having that anchor in the centre should not only allow Mainoo a bit more freedom but also give captain Bruno Fernandes the opportunity to focus solely on his offensive work.

While both Rasmus Hojlund and Joshua Zirkzee are showing promise with the latter happy to drop deep to start a build-up and link-up play, the Reds need a player like Fernandes to showcase his creativity. He should not be preoccupied with defensive duties - this should be left to Mainoo and Ugarte.

Having Fernandes dictating play in the upper third of the pitch should not only help the young centre-forwards but also bring into play Marcus Rashford who is on a journey to rediscover his form. At his worst, Rashford looks isolated on the left flank but with Fernandes given more freedom to create, there is an opportunity there for the winger to be reintroduced into the attack more regularly.

headline: Erik ten Hag might send £38m message with Manchester United starting XI decision
body: Matthijs de Ligt has Ajax, Juventus, Bayern Munich and Manchester United on his CV.

He's exclusively played for some of Europe's biggest clubs at just 25 years old and arrived in Manchester this summer with the sort of pedigree most footballers dream of having. United signed De Ligt from Bayern Munich for €45m (£38.4m) with a potential further €5m (£4.2m) in add-ons earlier this month and that seemed a reasonable fee.

Considering the experience De Ligt has and the potential upside to his arrival, his transfer seemed like smart business from United. Yet he may have to wait longer than expected to make his full debut for the club because Harry Maguire got the nod against Fulham last week.

De Ligt has been signed to start and the expectation is he will partner Lisandro Martinez, but Maguire started on the opening day and won't give up his place without a fight. Maguire enjoyed a renaissance last term and clawed his way back into the starting side, despite losing the captaincy, which demonstrated his impressive resilience and determination.

The 31-year-old has avoided injury for most of his career and was unfortunate to pick up two separate issues last term, a groin problem in December and April's calf injury. Some questioned the commitment of United's players last term and Wayne Rooney said in May that a few members of the dressing room were hiding behind injury, but that couldn't have been further from the truth with Maguire, who put his body on the line for the club.

United's defenders dropped like flies and Maguire could have opted for a spell on the sidelines to get fully fit when his body was tested in April - but he didn't and continued. Maguire played through a knock away from home against Bournemouth on April 13 and was spotted clutching his left thigh in pain. Although it seemed likely he would be substituted at half-time, he received treatment in the dressing room and emerged for the second period.

United played Coventry in the semi-finals of the FA Cup a week later and Maguire didn't train between games, yet he played 120 minutes and pushed through another issue. He is the type of character who will always be welcome in a United dressing room and his dedication hasn't gone unnoticed by fans, whose relationship with him has healed.

Maguire picked up where he left off against Fulham and was one of United's best players, making crucial interventions when Fulham were close to Andre Onana's goal and seeming to meet every ball that was crossed into the box with his head. It would be wrong to name Maguire on the bench against Brighton on the back of that impressive performance, which means the wait for De Ligt's full debut should go on.

De Ligt was introduced in the second half against Fulham and some fans will prefer him to start over Maguire at the Amex Stadium but it would send the wrong message to the squad. Maguire didn't put a foot wrong and the starting role should be his for as long as he continues to deliver strong performances. If Maguire underperforms then replacing him with De Ligt in the starting XI will be logical but he should start until then.

Understandably, there is a clamour among supporters to see De Ligt start because he is brand new and shiny, but Maguire was excellent last season and won't be displaced easily. He is certainly not a glamorous player but he's dependable. He put an awful two years behind him last season and will make more starts than most expect in 2024/25. The defender has fought for his starting place previously and will do so again.

headline: Jermaine Jenas removed from BBC presenting roles amid inappropriate behaviour claims
body: Former England and Tottenham Hotspur midfielder Jermaine Jenas has been dropped from his presenter role at the BBC. Having co-hosted The One Show with Alex Jones since 2020, and featuring prominently on Match of the Day 2 and during live matches, the decision comes after Jenas faced accusations.

The Daily Mail uncovered that the ex-Nottingham Forest and Newcastle player was let go from his annual £190,000 position due to claims of "inappropriate behaviour". This development was later confirmed by a BBC spokesman who informed the Mirror: "We can confirm that Jermaine Jenas is no longer part of our presenting line-up."

Jenas, who earned 21 caps for England, ended his playing career in 2016 at 34 years old, hampered by injuries throughout his time on the pitch. His transition to television saw him being considered as a potential replacement for Gary Lineker on Match of the Day.

Lineker himself voiced that Jenas would be a "good" choice for the position. Expressing ambition, Jenas had earlier stated to the Mail in 2023 about his aspirations to take over when Lineker steps down.

"I would obviously be up for it... it's Match of the Day and it would be a great opportunity," he stated. "I haven't thought that far ahead but I hosted Match of the Day 2, which was the first one I've ever done. I loved it, it felt comfortable to me, it felt normal, and I love doing The One Show as well.", reports Football London.
He added: "I feel quite blessed that I'm even in people's minds that it's something I could take on given how big the show actually is."

headline: Man United told how to land £500million financial boost thanks to Sir Jim Ratcliffe
body: Manchester United have been told they could earn up to £500million by selling the naming rights to a potential new stadium.

It was soon established after Sir Jim Ratcliffe's minority takeover that one of his priorities for the club was to improve their facilities. Old Trafford has deteriorated massively under the Glazers, falling well behind their competitors in Europe.

A task force was put together to explore the options for regeneration, and last month they concluded a new build would be the most prosperous option. A 100,000-seater ground on club-owned land adjacent to Old Trafford has been recommended.

It's estimated cost is £2billion - but a quarter of that could be reclaimed just from its name, according to Dr Rob Wilson, a professor of Applied Sports Finance at Sheffield Hallam University. With reports claiming United plan to keep Old Trafford as a second venue, he feels there's full scope for it to become a sponsorship vehicle.

Speaking hypothetically with regards to United's new kit partner Snapdragon, Dr Wilson told Casasdeapuestas.bet: "I think in terms of figures, if it was Snapdragon, they'd look to try and tie that into their shirt sponsorship and some of their other activities.

"It could do one or two things that could suppress the value because Snapdragon put another 30 on top of their £70million shirt sponsor to make it a round number. I think the stadium naming rights could be worth probably £50m a year in their own right.
"So if other companies get involved in that, then you've got a misalignment of brand. So Snapdragon might say that they need that and we'll do a £150m deal for shirt and stadium naming rights.
"You could see it go up a little bit higher but somewhere in the region of about £50m per season, they’d want something long-term. So that’s £500m over 10 years."

He also pointed out that giving a new stadium a sponsored name from the off - like the Etihad or the Emirates - tends to be better received than adapting an iconic stadium name, like Barcelona have done with the Spotify Camp Nou.

Dr Wilson feels Snapdragon in particular could be a wise choice of partner. The company, a subsidiary of US tech firm Qualcomm, offer long-term security, again much like Etihad and Emirates do for Man City and Arsenal respectively.

He continued: "What's really clever about what United are currently doing is that Snapdragon are about to go on the next wave of their journey, which is all tied up in tech, which means that it has longevity as a brand in the same way that Arsenal with Emirates and Manchester City with Etihad went for emergent Middle Eastern airlines that have got these big growth trajectories."

headline: Ex-Man Utd coach says how Sir Jim Ratcliffe would feel about Ruud van Nistelrooy taking over
body: Rene Meulensteen reckons Sir Jim Ratcliffe would consider replacing Erik ten Hag with Ruud van Nistelrooy – if Manchester United make a poor start to the season.

United are up and running in the Premier League after a 1-0 win over Fulham thanks to summer signing Joshua Zirkee’s late winner. Despite penning a new contract in the summer after leading the team to FA Cup glory, it is imperative Ten Hag improves on last season’s dismal eighth place in the Premier League.

A run of poor results would crank up the pressure on the Dutchman, who added Van Nistelrooy and former Utrecht boss Rene Hake to his backroom over the summer. It has been speculated that Van Nistelrooy could be first in line to steady the ship if Ten Hag is sacked.

Meulensteen, a first-team coach under Sir Alex Ferguson between 2007 and 2013, says the potential for Van Nistelrooy, who has previously managed PSV Eindhoven, to replace his countryman cannot be completely dismissed.
“I don’t think Erik ten Hag will be worried about Rudd van Nistelrooy potentially replacing him, he’s too focused on the job at hand,” Meulensteen told Gambling Zone.

“But who knows what the future will bring. If United stutter at the start of the season and the results don’t go their way, Sir Jim Ratcliffe would consider Van Nistelrooy. But at the moment they believe that Erik is the right man and now we need to see what happens.

“It is an interesting development, what has happened at Manchester United because Ten Hag brought in his trusted staff and many of them have gone. Now he has brought in his friend Rene Hake, who was manager of Utrecht, as well as Van Nistelrooy, so he has identified what he needs.”
Sign up to our United newsletter so you never miss an update from Old Trafford this season.

Meulensteen, 60, was surprised Van Nistelrooy, who was linked with the Burnley job before it went to Scott Parker, didn’t go back into management this summer. He said: “I've stayed in touch with him and he's obviously keen to carry on in management and I thought that's what he's going to do.

“I thought he may have gone to manage in Spain and then the Burnley rumours came up. I thought he would’ve continued as a manager so I was surprised when he joined United because I can see Ruud as a manager.

“I think he's had a taste of it and I think he wants more of it. Why has he chosen to go with Erik ten Hag? Probably the fact that there's a chance for him to go back to Manchester United where he had some fantastic years and great memories.
“He will be a good influence and a strong influence in the dressing room. People will respect him and I think he’s got a lot to teach all those young forwards.”

headline: Manchester United's plan for Sekou Kone revealed after agreement for wonderkid transfer
body: Manchester United have agreed a deal to sign defensive midfielder Sekou Kone in this summer window.
Kone currently plays for Guidars FC and impressed playing for Mali at the Under-17 World Cup in December, but he's set to complete a transfer to United before deadline day.
Although Erik ten Hag is in the market to sign a defensive midfielder and talks for Manuel Ugarte are progressing, the plan is for Kone to join up with the Under-21s.

It's understood the 18-year-old is considered as a player with high potential by United staff and he'll spend time training with the first-team at Carrington, which means he could be fast-tracked if he demonstrates he can operate at the level required around the senior group.
Manchester is close to 2,500 away from the African nation Mali and United will help Kone integrate into life in England as he settles into his new surroundings at a young age.
When United signed Alejandro Garnacho as a teenager in 2020, he undertook intensive English lessons and was given access to documentaries on the club and Manchester.
The same treatment will be given to Kone and more because Garnacho signed during the pandemic, which limited the care the club could give him after signing from Atletico Madrid.
Travis Binnion is the U21 manager at United and he will oversee Kone in a youth programme that will provide him with challenges in the EFL Trophy and in the Premier League 2.

Kone started his career with the JMG academy in Bamako, Mail, following in the footsteps of Tottenham Hotspur and Mali international Yves Bissouma. Mali beat Argentina to claim a third-place finish at the U17 World Cup in Indonesia and Kone played a pivotal role in that success.
United have also signed youth striker Chido Obi-Martin from Arsenal this summer and they continue to add talent to their academy to remain at the forefront of youth development.

headline: Manchester United include 16-year-old in first-team training after scoring two wonder goals
body: Jim Thwaites trained with Manchester United's first-team at Carrington on Wednesday, despite being just 16 years old.

The highly regarded Thwaites was among the academy players drafted into the session to make up numbers ahead of facing Brighton, with his inclusion feeling significant given his age. Thwaites is considered as one of the academy's leading prospects in his age group and won the club's Goal of the Season award for both Under-16 and Under-18 level last term.

The youngster's goal for the U18s was particularly important because it provided a late equaliser against Derby in added time. The U18s drew that game 2-2 thanks to Thwaites' goal in the dying seconds and his strike ensured their unbeaten record in the league continued.
The U18s' unbeaten run in the league was eventually ended - they lost just two games all season - but they still strolled to the title, finishing six points ahead of Manchester City.

The youngsters scored 78 goals during their winning Premier League North campaign and it's understood coaching staff at City acknowledged United's quality. City's U18s had won the league for four successive seasons and their staff privately conceded United had been a cut above last term.

Thwaites predominantly played for the U16s last season, but he made nine appearances for the U18s and was given two substitute appearances for the Under-21s. He is expected to be given a prominent role in Adam Lawrence's U18 side this season and the opportunity to join in with first-team training on Wednesday was recognition of his progress.

headline: Manchester United make decision on former Liverpool talent after electric start for academy
body: Manchester United youngster Ethan Ennis will not leave on loan in this transfer window.
The Manchester Evening News exclusively revealed last month that Ennis had signed a new United contract, as his previous deal with the club expired in the summer of 2025.
It's understood United have decided it's best for Ennis' development for him to spend the first half of the season with the Under-21s before the situation is assessed in January.
Ennis returned from a lengthy spell on the sidelines due to rupturing the anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) in his knee in October but has impressively got back up to speed.
The youngster ended last term with a flourish and looked sharp in friendlies against Rosenborg and Rangers this summer, coming on from the bench under the eye of Erik ten Hag.
Ennis scored in the U21s' opening game of the season against Arsenal and scored again on Tuesday night when producing the goal that sparked a 3-2 comeback against Barnsley.
The 19-year-old has started the new season in great form, scoring two goals in two appearances, and his professionalism in and out of training hasn't gone unnoticed at United.

Although some speculated that Ennis would leave on loan this summer after signing his new contract, he will continue to be an integral U21 player and could be allowed to leave on a temporary deal to challenge himself in a senior environment in the January window.
There were high hopes for Ennis when United signed him from rivals Liverpool and his minutes were carefully handled last season, which helped him return to full fitness.
Ennis signed his first professional contract immediately after celebrating his 17th birthday and only the most highly regarded academy talents are given pro deals so quickly.
The Chesire-born lad scored 10 goals in 19 appearances for United's Under-18s in 2021/22, his first full season at the club, and his finishing ability is one of his finest qualities.

headline: Jack Fletcher shows why Manchester United signed him from Man City with wondergoal in comeback
body: Manchester United's Under-21s completed a stunning 3-2 comeback against Barnsley thanks to a magnificent performance from Jack Fletcher in the EFL Trophy on Tuesday night.
The EFL Trophy sees Premier League sides field U21 teams against League One and League Two senior teams, and United got their new campaign under way against Barnsley.
Barnsley took a 2-0 lead in the first half thanks to goals from Vimal Yoganathan and they looked to be on their way to a comfortable victory until a dramatic ending unfolded.

United youngster Ethan Ennis made it 2-1 with a smart finish in the 81st minute and Fletcher, who was introduced from the bench, scored a few minutes late with an unbelievable goal, striking an instinctive volley from around 35 yards that dipped under the crossbar.
Fletcher's dad, Darren Fletcher, who is a first-team coach at United, was in the stands to watch the goal and the 17-year-old celebrated wildly with the pocket of travelling supporters.
However, there was still time for a winner and Fletcher scored again in the 87th minute, cutting inside and finding the corner to complete a sensational 3-2 comeback.
Jack Fletcher signed for United from Manchester City with his twin brother Tyler Fletcher last summer and was involved in multiple first-team training sessions last season.
Darren Fletcher's sons had been in the City academy for nine years but opted to move to United and a £1.25million fee was paid to sign the pair.
Both are highly regarded and sources at United believe they have first-team potential, which saw them given their first professional contracts with the club in April.
United will also play Doncaster and Huddersfield in their EFL Trophy group and the U21 side has been followed by a sold-out away support over the last few seasons in the competition.
"My two fondest memories are the FA Youth Cup final, with the brilliant crowd that night, and Stockport away in the EFL Trophy," said U21 manager Binnion in an interview with the MEN.

"Salford was good last season, bar the result, and Fleetwood was great. Garnacho’s late winner at Barrow was great and we can’t shy away from the two drubbings against Bolton, so I’m glad we’re not in their group this year.

"But that was a great learning experience. We are very lucky to work at a football club where the academy is integral and you feel it. There’s an expectation that comes with that, but there’s excitement from the fans that I don’t see from any other club towards its youth players"

headline: Man United star makes trophy vow after beating Man City and Chelsea rivals to 'unbelievable' award
body: England midfielder Grace Clinton says her aim is to win trophies with Manchester United after being voted PFA Young Player of the Year.

The 21-year-old joined the Reds from Everton in 2022 though she is yet to make a competitive appearance for the club, having since enjoyed loan spells at both Bristol City and Tottenham Hotspur. Clinton excelled for the latter last term, scoring four goals and assisting four others in 20 Women's Super League (WSL) appearances and playing an integral role in Spurs’ charge to their first ever Women’s FA Cup final, though she was ineligible to play against her parent club and eventual victors United at Wembley.

Her impressive form saw her receive her first senior England call up earlier this year. She made her first full start against Austria after two appearances off the bench, and duly made an impact with her first international goal in a 7-2 win for the Lionesses.

Clinton impressed so much at Tottenham that the club were keen to make her stay in the capital permanent. “She cannot stay because she’s not a part of us next year," manager Robert Vilahamn told The Athletic in April. "But if you ask me if I want to buy her, there would be a high potential I want to do that."

However United boss Skinner has always been unequivocal in his stance on the 21-year-old, insisting that her long-term future lies in Manchester. "All I hear is Tottenham want to keep Grace, of course they want to keep Grace," he said when quizzed on the club's plans for Clinton back in May. "She's a fantastic player.

"We don't get the credit that we identified her qualities at Everton, we brought her to Manchester United, gave her six months, sent her on loan at Bristol – she got experience. She then went on loan to Tottenham to get more experience. I don't think people recognise that – there is a plan for each individual we bring into the club.
"With Grace, it's absolutely worked. I want to bring her back to the club and be part of what we're doing because I think she has a huge say in how we'll play."

And Clinton has now voiced her commitment to the Reds, insisting her ambition is to add more silverware to the club's collection. "To go to Tottenham and get confidence was just amazing," she said at the start-studded awards ceremony on Tuesday night. "And to improve obviously personally. The aim is always to win trophies with Manchester United."

On her award, Clinton added: “It’s such an honour to be voted by the unbelievable players that play in this league. It’s the best league in the world. “To go out on loan, learning as a young player and being recognized is lovely. I’ve played with confidence and when you play with that then you see the best version of a player. Tottenham have been a massive part of my journey, and I can’t thank them enough. Goals and visualisation are important to me but most of all just enjoying playing. If I’m enjoying myself then I play my best football.”

Clinton also featured in the PFA Women's Team of the Year, alongside Manchester City stars Khadija 'Bunny' Shaw, Yui Hasegawa, Lauren Hemp, Khiara Keating, Alex Greenwood, Laia Aleixandri. She beat out a host of talented players to earn the award with Lauren James, Aggie Beever-Jones, Khiara Keating, Maya Le Tissier and Jess Park among the names on the Top Six shortlist.

headline: Man United have already made history but hard work is only just beginning
body: With a deft back-post finish, Lizzie Arnot wrote her name into the annals of Manchester United history. The date was August 19, 2018 and the Scotland international ensured the Reds' long-awaited renaissance began in style by netting a last-gasp winner against bitter rivals Liverpool in the League Cup.

The setting - in front of just 829 fans at an overcast Prenton Park - belied the enormity of the occassion. This was United's first competitive game in 13 years, their first competitive outing since the Glazer regime opted to disband their senior women's team after deeming it not to be part of the club's "core business".

The team was peppered with familar faces. Alex Greenwood, now captain of Manchester City, teed up Arnot to score the winner. Lauren James, who returned to childhood club Chelsea for what was - in 2021 - a British record fee, started in midfield, while current United stars Ella Toone, Millie Turner and Leah Galton also featured.
"For a team that has only been together for six weeks they weathered the storm quite well," manager Casey Stoney told BBC Radio 5 Live after the game.

"I recruited from the second tier, they've stepped up and shown they are more than capable of playing a level above that. There's no pressure from the club to get promotion but these players want to be playing in the top flight. They're history makers now."

In spite of Stoney's measured assessment of United's ambitions, the Reds did achieve promotion at the first time of asking, subsequently finishing fourth in their first season in the Women's Super League (WSL). And now, just six years on from that League Cup victory over Liverpool, United are a card-carrying member of the top flight's elite.

Stoney's departure in the summer of 2021 was a blow but her replacement, former Birmingham City boss Marc Skinner, has presided over the most successful period in the club's history. In 2022/23, the Reds took the title race to the final day, posting a club-record points tally in the process while also reaching the FA Cup final.

Last term, despite a disappointing fifth-place finish in the WSL, United beat Tottenham Hotspur to the FA Cup trophy; a reality which would have seemed inconceivable on that momentous afternoon at Prenton Park more than half a decade ago.

While the Reds have come a tremendously long way since then, it is fair to say this summer has not been without its challenges. First came the revelataion that Skinner had been handed a one-year contract extension - a decision which was not universally popular with the United fanbase.

Then came the exodus of some of the club's biggest stars. England goalkeeper Mary Earps left to join Paris Saint-Germain (PSG), citing United's transitional state and her own ambition to compete for more silverware as her chief motivating factors. Club captain Katie Zelem also departed on a free transfer, as did fan-favourite striker Lucia Garcia.

All of this unfolded has against the backdrop of Sir Jim Ratcliffe's barely concealed apathy towards Skinner's side. The INEOS chief gave a tone-deaf interview to Bloomberg, in which he conceded plans for the women's team were "TBC".

This was swiftly followed by United Women being ousted from their state-of-the-art Carrington training facility to make way for the men's team while their own building gets a revamp, though it is understood Skinner and his players will still have access to all the necessary facilities.

Still, the emergence of reports citing concern from the Professional Footballers Association (PFA) and of agents' apparent unwillingness to throw their players into the maelstrom that is Manchester United have been concerning.

That said, the Reds have recruited shrewdly in the transfer market, with the acquisition of Brighton & Hove Albion striker Elisabeth Terland and Swedish defender Anna Sandberg, in particular, inspiring excitement, while the appointment of Dan Ashworth as sporting director inspires hope of tangible change at the club.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said in an open letter to supporters last month.

"Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United. Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that.
“Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."

Indeed, six years on from that win over Liverpool, United now have all the ingredients in place to be truly successful. The Reds may already have made history in the years since their reformation but, with the WSL set to be more competitive than ever next term, it is clear the hard work is only just beginning.

headline: Dan Ashworth makes encouraging Man United gesture after Sir Jim Ratcliffe admission
body: Dan Ashworth has met with Manchester United Women's players after a turbulent summer for Marc Skinner's side.

United have come in for criticism of late number after a number of high-profile players, including England goalkeeper Mary Earps and captain Katie Zelem, were allowed to leave the club on free transfers, while co-owner Sir Jim Ratcliffe sparked controversy when he admitted plans for the women's team were "TBC".

Fan frustration was further compounded when it emerged Skinner's side were set to be moved out of their state-of-the-art training facility to accommodate the men's team while a £50m refurbishment of their Carrington facilities was underway.

However, Ashworth's long-awaited arrival from Newcastle United last month has offered some cause for optimism, with the sporting director having previously been a huge advocate for the growth of the women's game during his time with the Magpies and in his previous role at Brighton & Hove Albion. And the 53-year-old has now met with Skinner and his players as they ramp up their pre-season preparations at St George's Park.

Pictures shared on the club's website show Ashworth giving a speech to the women's first-team squad and shaking hands with stars such as Ella Toone and Millie Turner. This comes after he outlined his vision for the Reds in an open letter to supporters.

“Delivering a successful women’s team and a thriving, productive academy are both key objectives of my job, and I have a strong background in both areas," Ashworth said last month. "Women’s football was an important part of my remit in past roles with Newcastle United, Brighton & Hove Albion and the FA, and it will be the same at Manchester United.

"Women’s football is arguably the most exciting area of growth in the global game, and we want to be part of that. Last season’s FA Cup win was a fantastic landmark as our first major women’s trophy, and how we want to build on that with Marc, his staff and the players."
United finished fifth in the Women's Super League (WSL) last term and won the Women's FA Cup. They will get their new campaign underway against West Ham at Old Trafford on Saturday, September 22.

headline: Manchester United confirm 'insane' summer transfer as overhaul continues
body: Manchester United have confirmed the signing of Canada international Simi Awujo on a three-year deal.

The 20-year-old midfielder joins the Reds from the United States collegiate system, where she represented the University of Southern California’s USC Trojans. Awujo made her senior international debut for Canada at 18-years-old and has 19 caps for her country to date, reaching the quarter-finals of this summer’s Paris 2024 Olympic games.

Reflecting on her move to Manchester, Awujo said: “To say that I’m a professional footballer for Manchester United is insane. I’m so excited for the season ahead, what the future holds here and just to be a red devil. I cannot wait to play in front of the great Manchester United fans.”

Manager Marc Skinner added: “Simi is an exciting young talent who we are delighted has chosen to continue her football journey with us here at Manchester United. Our wonderful fans can expect a midfielder with international pedigree, who will only develop further in our competitive English game.”

Awujo is United's fifth signing of the summer following the arrivals of Dominique Janssen, Melvine Malard, Elisabeth Terland and Anna Sandber.
